docs.text: Welcome to iCafe iCafe is a tool for I ntra C ranial A rtery F eature E xtraction. It is used for the quantitative and comprehensive evaluation of intracranial vascular features, from both morphometry and signal intensity perspectives. For users, please start from User Guide . For developers in the VIL Lab, please start from Developer Guide . For more information, please refer to our paper Chen L, Mossa-Basha M, Balu N, Canton G, Sun J, Pimentel K, Hatsukami TS, Hwang JN, Yuan C. Development of a quantitative intracranial vascular features extraction tool on 3D MRA using semiautomated open-curve active contour vessel tracing. Magn. Reson. Med. 2018;79:3229–3238. doi: 10.1002/mrm.26961. A deformable model to trace tubular structures without boundary initialization ↩

Formatting can also be applied to blocks by putting the opening and closing tags on separate lines and adding new lines between the tags and the content. docs.title: Welcome to iCafe

docs.text: History of iCafe The intracranial artery feature extraction tool (iCafe, previously called BAFET) is a closed-source 1 software built based on the Tracing System 2 , an open source toolbox for biomedical imaging analysis. From 2016 to Oct 2021, iCafe was maintained by Li Chen 3 , Ph.D., at the University of Washington. From Nov 2021, iCafe will be maintained by Xin Wang, a new Ph.D. student at UW . Yu Wang from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Farsight ↩ Since Version 1.0.0 ↩ During that period, he was pursuing a Ph.D. degree in the Department of Electrical & Computer Engineering (ECE) at the University of Washington. He was co-advised by Professor Chun Yuan in the Vascular Imaging Lab (VIL) in the School of Medicine, and Professor Jenq-neng Hwang in ECE. ↩
docs.title: History of iCafe

docs.text: The intracranial artery feature extraction tool (iCafe, previously called BAFET) is a closed-source 1 software built based on the Tracing System 2 , an open source toolbox for biomedical imaging analysis. From 2016 to Oct 2021, iCafe was maintained by Li Chen 3 , Ph.D., at the University of Washington. From Nov 2021, iCafe will be maintained by Xin Wang, a new Ph.D. student at UW . Yu Wang from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Farsight ↩ Since Version 1.0.0 ↩ During that period, he was pursuing a Ph.D. degree in the Department of Electrical & Computer Engineering (ECE) at the University of Washington. He was co-advised by Professor Chun Yuan in the Vascular Imaging Lab (VIL) in the School of Medicine, and Professor Jenq-neng Hwang in ECE. ↩

docs.title: Introduction

docs.text: Introduction This is the introduction for iCafe users. PC Requirements System iCafe is currently built for Windows 10. Windows 7 and earlier versions were not tested. Linux/MacOS may be supported in the future. Hardware High performance GPUs are recommended, as the 3D rendering requires large calculation. At least 8GB memory is needed to perform the 3D filtering of images size of \(600\times600\times200\) . Remote desktop connection based on OpenGL is not supported, but remote software based on screen capturing, such as Teamviewer and VNC, are not affected. How to acquire or update iCafe Acquisition VIL lab members : The newest version is available under Public/LiChen/iCafe folder. Researchers outside the lab : Please contact Li Chen ( cluw@uw.edu ) for iCafe software with academic research agreement with VIL. Updating Generally, the new version will be compatible with older ones. For updating iCafe, just copy and paste iCafe.exe with replacement if not explicitly noted. Subversion upgrades (from 1.2 to 1.3) need copying whole folder.
docs.title: Introduction

docs.text: ① Menu: List of every functions ② Toolbar Frequently used functions ③ File tree data sources ④ Display area You can swtich among three kinds of views (scroll view, 3D view, and MPR view) in this area, for a best look at anatomical structures. Scroll view In this view three 2D images will be shown. There are three modes for showing different perspectives of the 3D scan. MIP mode In this mode, the 2D images are the Maximum Intensity Projections (MIPs) along the superior (S, z-axis), lateral (L), and posterior (P) directions by default. After clicking on the image, a red cross will show the 3D point with the highest intensity along the clicked 2D coordinate. At the same time, the information of the point, such as coordinates and intensity, will appear in Status Bar. If there is a snake within 2 pixels from clicked point, it will be selected and shown in blue. To avoid selecting a snake, hold Alt before click. To zoom in/out, click View -> Zoom in/Zoom out , or press = / - . To switch to the MIP mode from other modes, click View -> MIP -> Show Raw MIP in the menu, or press I . Slice mode When a 3D point is selected, press Space to look the three slices that contain the point from the three directions. To show different slices along the z-axis, drag the slider bar in Slider, or enter a slice number. For other methods to swiching slices, refer to the table below. Functions Mouse Scroll Keyboard larger Z scroll up Up smaller Z scroll down Down larger Y Ctrl + scroll up Ctrl + Up smaller Y Ctrl + scroll down Ctrl + Down larger X Shift + scroll up Right smaller X Shift + scroll down Left Cross-sectional mode When a point of a snake is selected , click View -> Show Normal View or press Ctrl + Space to enter Cross-sectional mode. In this mode, the planes in which the three images are located are perpendicular, and one of them is a cross-section of the snake at that point. An additional MPR image will also show on the right. You can swtich among points on the snake by referring to the table below. Functions Mouse Scroll Keyboard switch to previous point on the snake Scroll Up Up / Left / , switch to next point on the snake Scroll Down Down / Right / . You can change the information of the selected point on the snake in this mode by referring to the table below. Functions How change radius Ctrl + scroll mouse change x position Ctrl + Shift + scroll mouse change y position Ctrl + Alt + scroll mouse change z position Shift + scroll mouse Window level/width The window level (WL) and window width (WW) show in Parameter Bar. To adjust window level or width, drag in Scroll view by referring to the table below. Functions How increase window width drag right decrease window width drag left increase window level drag down decrease window level drag up Click the WL/WW tag in Parameter Bar to reset their values. Center clicked point in windows To adjust windows to the center of the clicked point, press \ , or click View -> Center View . ⑤ Setting panel showing tracing procedure with functions and parameter settings ⑥ Slider control display contents ⑦ Status Bar show warning, info, status of processing, details of point, trace ⑧ Parameter Bar show currently used parameters for tracing, crop region, etc

After clicking on the image, a red cross will show the 3D point with the highest intensity along the clicked 2D coordinate. At the same time, the information of the point, such as coordinates and intensity, will appear in Status Bar. If there is a snake within 2 pixels from clicked point, it will be selected and shown in blue. To avoid selecting a snake, hold Alt before click. To zoom in/out, click View -> Zoom in/Zoom out , or press = / - . To switch to the MIP mode from other modes, click View -> MIP -> Show Raw MIP in the menu, or press I .
